abstracts.cdata!:
This project (PSAC) is rated
            satisfactory: it achieved its objectives. All the components
            were effectively implemented resulting in substantially
            reducing government ownership of commercial enterprises and
            in fiscal saving. Furthermore, the project signaled stronger
            government commitment to enhance the role of the private
            sector. Key lessons learned include emphasizing the need for
            quality privatizations. The implementing agency should
            ensure that the process is widely publicized so as to
            attract as many competitive bidders as possible. The
            selected buyers should be committed to returning the
            enterprises to viability. At the same time, the buyers
            should be capable and willing to meet their outstanding
            obligations. Compliance can be achieved by writing default
            clauses into the sales contracts and invoking these clauses
            when default occurs. Because the project assumed that
            process issues could be resolved in a shorter time and the
            outsourcing process was oversimplified, unforeseen delays
            occurred in implementing the divestiture program.
            Fundamental issues like the legalities involved in
            transferring land titles need to be addressed system-wide.
            Combining this project with the Public Enterprise and
            Privatization Technical Assistance Project (PEPTA) was
            helpful as the two projects were coordinated as one
            operation with some mutual conditionalities, which
            effectively meant more supervision time for the PSAC
            privatization component.
